pullRequest.title: [DOCS] Refresh screenshots in machine learning tutorial
pullRequest.bodyText:
Related to #1505
This PR updates the screenshots in the rest of the machine learning tutorial pages so that they align with the dates on the Data Visualizer page.
Preview

https://stack-docs_1506.docs-preview.app.elstc.co/guide/en/machine-learning/master/ml-gs-jobs.html
https://stack-docs_1506.docs-preview.app.elstc.co/guide/en/machine-learning/master/ml-gs-results.html
https://stack-docs_1506.docs-preview.app.elstc.co/guide/en/machine-learning/master/ml-gs-forecasts.html

commit.message: [DOCS] Refreshes screenshots in machine learning tutorial

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -115,25 +132,31 @@ multiple time series based on a categorical field. For example, the
 `response_code_rates` job has a single detector that splits the data based on
 the `response.keyword` and then uses the `count` function to determine when the
 number of events is anomalous. You might use a job like this if you want to
-look at both high and low request rates partitioned by response code. When you
-view the results in the **Anomaly Explorer**, you can see separate swim lanes
-for the `404` and `200` responses:
+look at both high and low request rates partitioned by response code.
+
+Let's start by looking at the `response_code_rates` job in the
+**Anomaly Explorer**:
+
+. Select the *Anomaly Detection* tab in *{ml-app}* to see the list of your
+{anomaly-jobs}.
+
+. Click the grid icon in the *Actions* column for your `response_code_rates` job
+to view its results in the **Anomaly Explorer**.
+
+For this particular job, you can choose see separate swim lanes for each client
